awd_titl_txt: CAREER: A Local-Nonlocal Coupling Framework for Tissue Damage in Fluid-Structure Interaction
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to develop a new mathematical framework and the corresponding high-performance open source software for addressing fundamental open questions on multiscale and multiphysics modeling of soft tissue damage process, with the ultimate goal of improving the understanding of heart valve damage mechanisms. The resultant framework will have substantial impacts in heart valve operation and research, and will potentially contribute towards more rigorous interventional and surgical procedures. The computational tool and the methodology developed in this project can also be used efficiently in a wide range of physical and biological problems. For the educational component, this project will provide an excellent research and outreach platform for promoting female and under-represented groups in Science, Technology,  Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) fields in a range of educational levels from middle school to young researchers post graduate school. These activities include (1) introducing a heart function module in a summer outreach program to expose middle school girls to science and engineering, (2) providing research opportunities for undergraduate students from primarily undergraduate institutions to promote the students' engagement in scientific studies, and (3) organizing an annual high-performance computing (HPC) workshop and a multiscale/multiphysics modeling topical workshop to promote the participation of female students and researchers in the areas of applied mathematics and scientific computing.

Technically, a central theme of the research component is the development of a computational approach which models the physically realistic process of heart valve degradation under long-term cyclic hemodynamic loading with the objective of understanding tissue fatigue mechanisms. Emphasis will be placed on modeling the fiber-level tissue damage induced by cyclic hemodynamic loading and its long-term progression. Specifically, the computational domain is composed of three subregions: the fluid (blood) simulated as incompressible Newtonian flow, the fracture thin structure (damaged heart valves) modeled by the nonlocal peridynamic shell theory, and the thin structure (undamaged heart valves and aortic walls) described by a classical hyperelastic shell model. These three subregions will be numerically coupled to each other with proper interface boundary conditions. Novel constitutive models and corresponding numerical schemes will be developed, and new local-nonlocal coupling strategies will also be designed. A powerful computational open source software will be developed, which not only will contribute to advance the knowledge of soft tissue damage, but also will increase the range of capabilities for computer simulation of problems in long-term materials and manufacturing damage progression in general.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Bioprosthetic heart valves (BHVs) consist of multiple thin leaflets fabricated from exogenously cross-linked collagenous tissues. These leaflets are designed to open in response to blood flow in one direction and close when the flow reverses. Despite their widespread use, BHVs have a limited lifespan of 10-15 years, and the underlying mechanisms leading to their failure remain poorly understood. This project aims to develop a new mathematical framework and corresponding high-performance open-source software, utilizing peridynamics--a nonlocal model which describes material deformation and damage simultaneously--to address open questions in the soft tissue damage process.

Regarding intellectual merits, this work has led to the development of novel constitutive relationships, mathematical analyses, and numerical tools for nonlocal models. Local-nonlocal coupling strategies and data-driven surrogate approaches have also been designed to accelerate the simulations. The major outcomes of this research can be categorized into three interrelated parts: the physics-based and data-driven discovery of novel nonlocal models to describe the mechanical responses of heart valve tissues; the development of mathematical theory and robust numerical methods for the proposed nonlocal models; and the design of multiscale/multiphysics modeling strategies for soft tissues.

For model discovery of heart valve tissue, emphasis has been placed on modeling the fiber-level (mesoscale) tissue mechanical responses and damage. To derive predictive tissue models from first principles, the PI has developed the data-driven framework of learning mathematically well-posed and physically consistent nonlocal models through a constrained optimization framework. This approach formulates the constitutive law in the form of a nonlocal neural operator, allowing the neural network to learn mappings between function spaces and enabling cross-resolution predictions. The architecture of the neural network architecture resembles fiber-reinforced peridynamics models, allowing it to uncover material damage and heterogeneity by learning nonlocal kernels. The method provides a data-driven workflow for complex material modeling directly from experimental measurements, and has been successfully applied on learning the heart valve tissue responses and collagen fiber orientation. As illustrated in figure 1, this model significantly outperforms the conventional constitutive models in prediction accuracy. The learnt fiber architecture also shows consistency with observations from polarized spatial frequency domain imaging. Consequently, this method enables the discovery of detailed physical processes in collagen fiber reorganization during BHV failure.

For numerical and mathematical analysis, the PI has developed a meshfree discretization method for peridynamics, utilizing a quadrature rule as an equality constrained least squares problem. This approach provides a high-order approximation for integrals in nonlocal governing equations, and therefore preserves asymptotic compatibility. Moreover, the PI has developed Neumann-type and Dirichlet-type boundary conditions for state-based peridynamic models, and has validated these numerical tools with available experimental data on soda-lime glass crack initiation. To account for potential uncertainties in heart valve micromechanical properties, a stochastic nonlocal model and the corresponding numerical method are also developed. Rigorous well-posedness and convergence analyses were conducted to ensure the reliability of these models and methods.

For multiscale and multiphysics modeling, the PI has developed and analyzed a concurrent framework for coupling peridynamics with the corresponding classical elastic model. By utilizing the Robin boundary condition and the Aitken relaxation method, this approach robustly accelerates the coupling process. The developments were further extended to integrate data-driven material models with finite element models. Neural operators were trained offline to capture the underlying and possibly unknown fine-scale dynamics, which were then coupled with standard PDE solvers to predict multiscale systems under new boundary and initial conditions during the coupling stage.

In terms of broader impacts, the data-driven nonlocal modeling approach has the potential to revolutionize the monitoring of cardiovascular systems through noninvasive measurements, offering a deeper understanding of BHV failure. The developed models and numerical tools not only establish a computational framework for studying heart valve tissues but also provide mathematical theory and powerful computational software applicable to a wide range of physical and biological systems. These outcomes have practical industry applications. For instance, the developed multi-scale material modeling framework offers a predictive tool with uncertainty quantification and has been adopted by Global Engineering & Materials Inc. for data-driven control in additive manufacturing processing (see figure 2).

The research component of this project is also closely integrated with its educational objectives. One undergraduate student and three graduate students have received training through this project. The research results have been introduced into three undergraduate and graduate courses at Lehigh University. Additionally, the PI has co-organized a CBMS conference on Deep Learning and Numerical PDEs, which provided training for junior researchers and graduate students from the US, Europe, and Asia. To further promote the retention of female students and researchers from Lehigh, as well as those from local high schools and neighboring colleges, this project has also supported an annual high performance computing workshop for staff, faculty and students at Lehigh university, neighboring institutions, and the local community, which offers valuable educational experiences to these audiences.


Last Modified: 08/31/2024
Modified by: Yue Yu
